metadata.title: Children's Drawing Interpretation - Feature-Based Rules for RAG
metadata.purpose: Map visual features to psychological/developmental interpretations

sources.title: 12 Must-Know Facts about Children's Drawing Interpretation
sources.author: Michal Wimmer

metadata.usage: For vision model output to psychological interpretation

interpretation.primary_meaning: Strong presence, confidence, desire to be noticed and involved
personality_indicators: Wants to be noticed/center of attention
interpretation.emotional_state: Positive - indicates engagement, confidence, and self-assurance
behavioral_correlates: Likes to be part of what's going on
Strong presence that cannot be ignored

developmental_context.age_2_to_3: Normal for structured scribbling stage - fills entire pages

combine_with_features.strong_pressure: Very confident, willful, possibly rebellious child
combine_with_features.red_color: High energy, dominant, competitive, wants to win

interpretation_rules.contrast_with: Small figures at edges = opposite meaning (social difficulty)

interpretation_rules.feature_name: Small figures at edge of page with empty center

interpretation.primary_meaning: Difficulty in social interaction, feels presence is not meaningful to others
interpretation.emotional_state: Negative - indicates social difficulty or emotional distress

developmental_context.all_ages: Not developmentally appropriate at any age - requires attention

combine_with_features.weak_pressure: Severe lack of confidence and helplessness

interpretation_rules.clinical_significance: CRITICAL - Potential indicator of social rejection or distress
interpretation_rules.recommended_action: Monitor over time with multiple drawings (6+ months). Consider professional consultation.

visual_indicators.placement: aligned on bottom edge of page

interpretation.primary_meaning: Normal developmental stage - seeks balance, stability, and security
interpretation.emotional_state: Neutral to positive - normal developmental indicator

developmental_context.age_4_to_5: Beginning to appear - first attempts at spatial organization
developmental_context.age_7_to_9: Still present - gradual transition to perspective
developmental_context.age_9_plus: Should begin transitioning to perspective drawing

interpretation_rules.clinical_notes: This is developmentally appropriate and NOT a concern. Creates feeling of security for child.

interpretation.primary_meaning: Age-dependent: Normal for young children, may indicate issues if older

developmental_context.age_1_to_3: Normal - scribble stage, no spatial awareness expected
developmental_context.age_5_plus: May indicate developmental delay, emotional distress, or disorganization

interpretation_rules.clinical_significance: Only concerning if persists beyond age 5

visual_indicators.example: legs visible through horse body, people visible in house

interpretation.primary_meaning: 'Intellectualism' - child draws what they KNOW, not what they SEE
interpretation.developmental_significance: Normal cognitive stage - represents knowledge over perception

developmental_context.age_7_plus: Should gradually decrease as visual realism develops

interpretation_rules.clinical_notes: NOT a concern - natural developmental phase

interpretation.primary_meaning: Confidence, willfulness, strong personality, desire for control
interpretation.emotional_state: Positive when balanced; may indicate frustration/anger if excessive
behavioral_correlates: Wants to do things their own way
Resists being told what to do

combine_with_features.red_color: High energy, competitive, wants to be winner

warning_signs.excessive_pressure: If repeatedly pierces paper, may indicate anger issues
warning_signs.with_aggression_themes: Combined with violent content requires attention

interpretation.primary_meaning: Lack of confidence, sense of helplessness coping with outside world
interpretation.emotional_state: Negative - indicates low self-esteem, anxiety, or depression

important_exclusion.check_first: Rule out low muscle tone (physiological cause)
important_exclusion.medical_consideration: If child has physical weakness, this may not be psychological

interpretation_rules.clinical_significance: HIGH - Possible distress indicator if not physiological
interpretation_rules.recommended_action: Check for physiological causes first, then monitor emotional state

interpretation.primary_meaning: Emotional difficulty, anxiety, possibly fear or distress

interpretation_rules.clinical_significance: CRITICAL - Strong indicator of emotional distress

interpretation.primary_meaning: Anxiety, perfectionism, difficulty coping with unexpected situations
interpretation.emotional_state: Negative - indicates performance anxiety and stress
behavioral_correlates: Loses temper when unable to complete perfectly
Extremely careful not to go outside lines

interpretation_rules.clinical_significance: HIGH - Indicates anxiety and control issues

interpretation.primary_meaning: Enthusiasm, energy, dominant and extroverted personality
personality_indicators: Likes to be center of attention
behavioral_correlates: First to come to mind when discussing colors

warning.monitor_if: Combined with violence themes or excessive pressure

interpretation.primary_meaning: Calm, peaceful behavior with harmonious social relations
behavioral_correlates: Needs to express wishes and desires

interpretation.primary_meaning: Nature-lover with fresh outlook, quick learner
MYTH DEBUNKED: Does NOT indicate depression
actual_reasons: Likes strong contrast with white page
interpretation.evidence: Children in Ghetto Theresienstadt used bright colors despite terrible conditions

interpretation_rules.clinical_significance: NOT a depression indicator by itself - must have other indicators

interpretation.emotional_state: Very positive - indicates happiness and security
interpretation.developmental_context: Typical of ages 5-7 in loved, secure children

interpretation_rules.feature_name: Sudden regression to earlier developmental stage

interpretation.primary_meaning: Protection mechanism - returns to familiar, safer stage during stress
interpretation.significance: CLEAR indicator of fear or distress
behavioral_correlates: May also regress in other behaviors (bedwetting, pacifier)

interpretation_rules.requirements: Must have previous drawings to establish baseline
source_references: Wimmer: Section 6.1 - Divergence from personal sequence

interpretation_rules.feature_name: Shading or heavy marks on human figures or body parts

interpretation.primary_meaning: CRITICAL - Could suggest sexual abuse or sense of rejection
Multiple indicators increase concern level significantly

interpretation_rules.critical_rule: Multiple drawings over 6+ months required for accurate assessment

interpretation_rules.feature_name: Tadpole figures (head with legs, no body)

interpretation.developmental_significance: First meaningful images - normal and expected

interpretation_rules.feature_name: Detailed figures with body, limbs, facial features
House with locks, fences, or barriers

interpretation.primary_meaning: Need for protection, emotional insecurity, creating boundaries

interpretation_rules.developmental_context: Can be response to family changes (divorce, relocation)

visual_indicators.trunk: represents personality, ability to withstand stress

interpretation.canopy_small: Limited view of potential or future
interpretation.canopy_large_proportional: Rich, balanced life with strong foundation

critical_principles: NEVER rely on single indicator - always cross-reference multiple features
Requires multiple drawings over 6+ months minimum for accurate assessment
Age context is essential - same feature means different things at different ages
Always check for physiological causes before psychological interpretation
Parental involvement is critical for full understanding
interpretation_process: 2. Look up each feature in rules database
7. Flag any critical indicators for professional attention

confidence_levels.high: Feature explicitly matches rule with clear context
confidence_levels.medium: Feature partially matches, needs additional context

debunked_myths.reality: False - often chosen for contrast or availability
debunked_myths.evidence: Children in terrible conditions used bright colors

debunked_myths.reality: False - show pressure, style, character differences

debunked_myths.myth: Not liking to draw means motor problems
debunked_myths.reality: Partly true - many reasons including preference, intervention, criticism
False - monsters don't mean fear, line quality matters more
